slideshow.caption: Arctic ice shrinks to record low
slideshow.longDescription: In 2012, the Arctic ice cap shrank to the smallest size yet recorded. If the polar ice caps continue to melt at the present rate, there could be no Arctic ice at all during the summer by mid-century.

slideshow.caption: Reservoir dries in South Africa
slideshow.longDescription: The Theewaterskloof reservoir in South Africa was filled to capacity in 2014. By 2017, after three years of punishing drought, it had lost 73% of its water. Droughts are becoming more common as the climate changes.

slideshow.caption: Hurricane Harvey causes flooding in Houston, Texas
slideshow.longDescription: In 2017, Hurricane Harvey dumped up to 1.2 meters (4 feet) on eastern Texas, making it the largest single rainfall event recorded in US history. The storm displaced 30,000 people, destroyed 200,000 homes and businesses and caused $126 billion in property damage. Global warming is expected to make such disasters more common.

slideshow.caption: Record wildfires in California
slideshow.longDescription: Global warming increases the risk of wildfires. In 2017, California experienced its largest wildfire on record. The burned areas, highlighted in red, totaled nearly 1,140 square kilometers (440 square miles). Unburned areas are colored green.

slideshow.caption: Coral bleaching in American Samoa
slideshow.longDescription: Vast areas of American Samoa’s coral reefs were damaged during a major global bleaching event in the Pacific Ocean in 2015. Temperature increases of even a few degrees can cripple entire reef systems, making them vulnerable to global warming. In 2016, Australia’s Great Barrier Reef lost 30% of its coral in a single year after a record heat wave.
slideshow.credit: © XL Catlin Seaview Survey - The Ocean Agency - Richard Vevers

slideshow.caption: Shrinking glaciers in Switzerland
slideshow.longDescription: The Trift Glacier in Switzerland retreated 1.2 kilometers (0.7 miles) between 2006 and 2017. Glaciers all over the world are shrinking as the climate warms.
slideshow.credit: James Balog/Aurora Photos (before), Matthew Kennedy/Earth Vision Institute/Aurora Photos (after)

slideshow.caption: Hurricane Harvey floods roads in Houston
slideshow.longDescription: Many roads in Houston, Texas, flooded after up to 1.2 meters (4 feet) of rain fell during Hurricane Harvey in 2017. Millions of people worldwide live in coastal communities that are vulnerable to increased precipitation, more destructive storm surges and rising sea levels.
slideshow.credit: Google (before), Alyssa Schukar/The New York Times/Redux Pictures (after)

slideshow.caption: Bolivia’s Lake Poopó runs dry
slideshow.longDescription: In wet periods, Lake Poopó is Bolivia’s second largest lake, covering 3,000 square kilometers (1,200 square miles). Already shrinking as water was diverted for mining and agriculture, the lake ran completely dry after a major drought in 2016. Many lakes, rivers and reservoirs are shrinking as the climate warms.

slideshow.caption: Heavy flooding in Cambodia
slideshow.longDescription: Roughly 3,000 square kilometers (1,200 square miles) of rice fields were destroyed by flooding of the Mekong and Tonlé Sap Rivers in 2013, affecting half a million people. Extreme floods are expected to increase as a warming climate raises sea levels and heavy rainfall increases in certain areas.

slideshow.caption: Melting ice in Greenland
slideshow.longDescription: Global warming is having dramatic effects in the Arctic. In 2016, Greenland’s ice sheet became covered by rivers and lakes (visible in blue) earlier in the summer than in previous years. Formed from melting ice, the liquid water digs deep holes into the ice sheet, allowing the water to drain to the bottom of the ice sheet and into the ocean, contributing to sea level rise.

slideshow.caption: Massive wildfires in Argentina
slideshow.longDescription: Wildfires are worsening as the climate warms. During a severe drought in 2017, about 10,000 square kilometers (4,000 square miles) of grassland were destroyed by numerous fires that spread through the dry Pampas region in Argentina. Burned areas are colored red.

slideshow.caption: Drought speeds reservoir loss in Iraq
slideshow.longDescription: The Qadisyah Reservoir in Iraq, which was already being drained for human use, lost water even faster following a drought in 2007. The Middle East could face increasing water shortages as the climate warms, runoff from snow melt is reduced and droughts become more frequent and severe.

slideshow.caption: Argentina flooding damages soybean crop
slideshow.longDescription: Flooding from unusually heavy rain in 2016 and 2017 destroyed much of Argentina’s soybean crop. So many soybeans were destroyed that global prices rose worldwide in response to the reduced supply. Global warming could increase the severity of both floods and droughts.

slideshow.caption: British Virgin Islands stripped of greenery by Hurricane Irma
slideshow.longDescription: Once covered in greenery, the British Virgin Islands were left brown and denuded by Hurricane Irma’s record winds in 2017. Hurricanes could become increasingly destructive as the climate warms, making the type of devastation seen after Irma more common.

slideshow.caption: Tropical glaciers are disappearing
slideshow.longDescription: Even near the equator, tall mountains used to be capped with ice year round. But tropical glaciers could disappear entirely in a few decades because of global warming. The Sudirman Range on the Pacific island of New Guinea has already lost most of its ice (highlighted in light blue).
